{{Coord|43|44|4.74|N|7|25|16.8|E|scale:1563_type:landmark_region:MC|display=title}} {{Infobox Grand Prix race report |Type = F1 |Country = Monaco |Grand Prix = Monaco |Date = 14 May |Year = 1961 |Image = Circuit de Monaco 1950.png |Official name = XIX [[Monaco Grand Prix|Grand Prix de Monaco]] |Location = [[Circuit de Monaco]]
[[Monte Carlo]]/[[La Condamine]], [[Monaco]] |Course = Street circuit |Course_mi = 1.954 |Course_km = 3.145 |Distance_laps = 100 |Distance_mi = 195.4 |Distance_km = 314.5 |Weather = Sunny |Pole_Driver = [[Stirling Moss]] |Pole_Country = UK |Pole_Team = [[Team Lotus|Lotus]]-[[Coventry Climax|Climax]] |Pole_Time = 1.39.1 |Fast_Driver = [[Richie Ginther]] |Fast_Team = [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] |Fast_Time = 1.36.3 |Fast_Lap = 84 |Fast_Country = US |Fast_Driver2 = [[Stirling Moss]] |Fast_Team2 = Lotus-Climax |Fast_Country2 = UK |Fast_Lap2 = 85 |First_Driver = [[Stirling Moss]] |First_Country = UK |First_Team = Lotus-Climax |Second_Driver = [[Richie Ginther]] |Second_Country = USA |Second_Team = Ferrari |Third_Driver = [[Phil Hill]] |Third_Country = USA |Third_Team = Ferrari }} [[Image:Lotus 18 Stirling Moss Monaco 1961.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The ''[[Rob Walker Racing]]'' [[Lotus 18]] which [[Stirling Moss]] drove to victory in the 1961 Monaco Grand Prix.]] The '''1961 Monaco Grand Prix''' was a [[Formula One]] motor race held on 14 May 1961 on the [[Circuit de Monaco]] in [[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]]. It was race 1 of 8 in both the [[1961 World Championship of Drivers]] and the [[1961 International Cup for Formula One Manufacturers]]. It was also the first World Championship race under the new 1.5 litre engine regulations.{{cite web |url=http://www.grandprix.com/gpe/rr095.html |title=Grand Prix Results, Monaco GP, 1961 |publisher=grandprix.com |accessdate=20 September 2015}} == Report == === Qualifying === The erratic yearly variations in Monaco's qualifying regulations saw grid places guaranteed for works teams and past winners in 1961.{{cite book |last=Lang |first=Mike |title=Grand Prix! Vol 1 |publisher=Haynes Publishing Group |year=1981 |isbn=0-85429-276-4 |page=180}} Therefore, the five works teams were awarded two places each on the grid, while [[Stirling Moss]] and [[Maurice Trintignant]] earned spots. This left nine drivers to fight over four remaining slots. A fifth opened up when [[Innes Ireland]] crashed during the final practice session, breaking his leg. Moss took pole position from [[Richie Ginther]] and [[Jim Clark]], with [[Graham Hill]] and [[Phil Hill]] on the second row. === Race === Ginther led Clark and Moss into the first corner but Clark quickly ran into trouble with a faulty fuel pump. Ginther dropped to third on lap 14, when Moss and Bonnier passed him in quick succession. At quarter distance, Moss had an impressive 10 second lead (in the underpowered [[Lotus 18]]-[[Coventry-Climax|Climax]])Kettlewell, Mike. "Monaco: Road Racing on the Riviera", in Northey, Tom, editor. ''World of Automobiles'' (London: Orbis, 1974), Volume 12, p.1384. but the Ferraris of Hill and then Ginther found their way around Bonnier and began to close the gap. At half distance, Moss' lead was 8 seconds, and down to 3 seconds on lap 60. Ginther moved into second on lap 75 and tried to close the gap, but Moss proved able to match his lap times, despite the [[Ferrari 156|156]]'s horsepower advantage.Kettlewell, p.1384. == Classification == {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- ! Pos !! No !! Driver !! Constructor !! Laps !! Time/Retired !! Grid !! {{TennisEventInfo|1997|Monte Carlo Open| | date= 21 – 27 April | edition=91st | category=[[ATP Masters Series|ATP Super 9]] | surface=[[Clay court|Clay]] / outdoor | location=[[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]] | venue=[[Monte Carlo Country Club]] | champs= {{flagicon|CHL}} [[Marcelo Ríos]] {{cite web|title=1997 Monte Carlo Men's Singles draw|url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/scores/archive/monte-carlo/410/1997/draws?matchType=singles|website=www.atpworldtour.com|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] (ATP)}} | champd= {{flagicon|USA}} [[Donald Johnson]] / {{flagicon|USA}} [[Francisco Montana]] {{cite web|title=1997 Monte Carlo Men's Doubles draw|url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/scores/archive/monte-carlo/410/1997/draws?matchType=doubles|website=www.atpworldtour.com|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] (ATP)}} }} The '''1997 Monte Carlo Open''' was a men's [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Clay court|outdoor clay courts]]. It was the 91st edition of the [[Monte Carlo Masters|Monte Carlo Open]], and was part of the [[ATP Masters Series|ATP Super 9]] of the [[1997 ATP Tour]]. It took place at the [[Monte Carlo Country Club]] in [[Roquebrune-Cap-Martin]], France, near [[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]], from 21 April through 27 April 1997. Seventh-seeded [[Marcelo Ríos]] won the singles title. ==Finals== ===Singles=== {{main|1997 Monte Carlo Open – Singles}} {{flagicon|CHL}} [[Marcelo Ríos]] defeated {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Àlex Corretja]], 6–4, 6–3, 6–3 *It was Marcelo Ríos' 1st title of the year, and his 5th overall. It was his 1st Masters title of the year, and overall. ===Doubles=== {{main|1997 Monte Carlo Open – Doubles}} {{flagicon|USA}} [[Donald Johnson]] / {{flagicon|USA}} [[Francisco Montana]] defeated {{flagicon|NED}} [[Jacco Eltingh]] / {{flagicon|NED}} [[Paul Haarhuis]], 7–6, 2–6, 7–6 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://montecarlotennismasters.com}} * [http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/tournaments/monte-carlo/410/overview Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) tournament profile]
{{Monte Carlo Masters tournaments}} {{1997 ATP Masters Series tournaments}} {{1997 in tennis}} [[Category:1997 ATP Tour|Monte Carlo Open]] [[Category:1997 Monte Carlo Open| ]] [[Category:Monte-Carlo Masters]] [[Category:1997 in Monégasque sport]] [[Category:Monaco stubs]] {{Monaco-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Main article|Al-Qaeda}} '''Al-Qaeda''' has conducted operations and recruited members in '''Africa'''. It has included a number of bombing attacks in [[North Africa]] and supporting parties in civil wars in [[Eritrea]] and [[Somalia]]. From 1991 to 1996, [[Osama bin Laden]] and other [[al-Qaeda]] leaders were based in [[Sudan]].
==Algeria== {{Main article|Al-Qaeda Organization in the Islamic Maghreb|Insurgency in the Maghreb (2002–present)}} {{See also|December 11, 2007 Algiers bombings}}
An insurgency is being waged by the [[Al-Qaeda Organization in the Islamic Maghreb|Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat]] (which is called today as the [[al-Qaeda Organization in the Islamic Maghreb]]) against the [[Government of Algerian|Algerian government]]. It is a spin-off to the [[Algerian Civil War]] that ended in 2002, and has been linked to bombings in [[2007 Algiers bombings (disambiguation)|Algiers]], [[2007 Batna bombing|Batna]] and [[2007 Dellys bombing|Dellys]] in 2007.
The group has declared its intention to attack Algerian, [[France|French]], American and Spanish targets. It has been designated as a [[U.S. State Department list of Foreign Terrorist Organizations|Foreign Terrorist Organization]] by the [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]], and similarly classed as a terrorist organization by the [[European Union]].
==Eritrea== As soon as the allied Somali and Ethiopian forces drove the Islamic Courts Union (ICU) out of Somalia in January 2007, U.S. accused Eritrea of providing safe haven for some of their leadership.<ref>[http://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2007-04/2007-04-23-voa66.cfm?CFID=144318625&CFTOKEN=43657409 U.S. accuses Eritrea on supporting islamists]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> America also condemned Eritrea since it continued to "fund, arm, train and advise the insurgents" attacking the Somalia government.<ref>[http://www.voanews.com/uspolicy/2007-04-26-voa3.cfm U.S. condemns Eritrean assistance of islamists] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080604072925/http://www.voanews.com/uspolicy/2007-04-26-voa3.cfm |date=2008-06-04 }}</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/international/story/0,,2052758,00.html US blames Eritrea over Somalian insurgency]</ref> According to a regional Somali government, some Eritrean soldiers were also sighted working with Arab and al-Qaeda fighters against the Somalian government, and the foreign alliance attacked government positions.<ref>[http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Islamist_supporters_al-Qaeda_terrorists_attacked_us_Somalia_governor.shtml allied ICU, Al-Qaeda and Eritrean fighters attack government positions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070615022638/http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Islamist_supporters_al-Qaeda_terrorists_attacked_us_Somalia_governor.shtml |date=2007-06-15 }}</ref>
In 2007 there were reports that the Eritrean government is sheltering the leadership of the insurgency in Somalia.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.economist.com/world/africa/displaystory.cfm?story_id=9597711 |title="The Economist" sites alliance of the islamists and Eritrea |access-date=2008-09-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612090054/http://www.economist.com/world/africa/displaystory.cfm?story_id=9597711 |archive-date=2008-06-12 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> The United Nations continued to report of Eritrean assistance to Somalis with alleged links to al-Qaeda. Accordingly, the UN Security Council said that Eritrea has secretly supplied "huge quantities of arms" to a Somali insurgent group with alleged ties to al Qaeda, in violation of an international arms embargo and despite the deployment of African peacekeepers" adding that it has been "provided to the [[Al-Shabaab (Somalia)|al-Shabaab]] (an extremist group which emerged within the ICU’s armed forces and is led by a kinsman and [[protégé]] of the ICU council leader Sheikh [[Hassan Dahir Aweys]], [[Aden Hashi Farah "Eyrow"]], who trained in Afghanistan with al-Qaeda before returning to Somalia after 9/11<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.bdafrica.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2883&Itemid=5821 |title=Al Shabaab and the insurgency in Somalia |access-date=2008-09-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913202251/http://www.bdafrica.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2883&Itemid=5821 |archive-date=2008-09-13 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>) by and through Eritrea" since December 2006.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/africa/07/26/somalia.arms.ap/index.html |title=the Eritrean government is giving arms to Somalis with Al Qaeda ties |access-date=2008-09-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226103102/http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/africa/07/26/somalia.arms.ap/index.html |archive-date=2008-02-26 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> Sheikh Aweys himself and other members of the Islamic Courts Union who are wanted by the U.S. over suspected links to al-Qaeda (the UN has Sheikh Aweys on a list of individuals "belonging to or associated with" al Qaeda, which he denies<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L06862375.htm |title=Somali on the United Nations list of individuals "belonging to or associated with" al Qaeda |access-date=2008-09-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080727003927/http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L06862375.htm |archive-date=2008-07-27 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>) organized a [[congress]] in Eritrea to strengthen their militant opposition to the Somalia transitional government.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/B54AA636-A618-459C-9FC3-C785A5FC7D39.htm |title=Islamic Courts Union leaders wanted by the US over suspected links to al-Qaeda. |access-date=2008-09-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080616181429/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/B54AA636-A618-459C-9FC3-C785A5FC7D39.htm |archive-date=2008-06-16 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
==Kenya== In 2002 another successful terrorist attack in [[Kenya]] after the [[1998 United States embassy bombings|U.S. embassy bombing]], a [[2002 Mombasa attacks|car bomb attack on a Mombasa resort hotel]] popular among Israeli tourists claimed the lives of 15 people. The hotel bombing occurred 20 minutes after a failed attack on an airplane, when a terrorist fired an [[Strela 2|SA-7]] [[Man-portable air-defense systems|man-portable air-defense system]] against an Israeli airliner carrying 261 passengers, which was taking off from the airport; the missile seemingly failed to track its target, nor did it detonate, and landed in an empty field.
==Libya== On 3 November 2007, al-Zawahiri claimed in a 28-minute recording posted on an Islamic website that "... members of the [[Libyan Islamic Fighting Group]] announce that they are joining the al-Qaeda group ..." According to [[Al Jazeera]], [[Abu al-Laith]] appeared to be the leader of the new Libyan wing. Fighting Islamic Group first announced its presence in 1995, vowing to overthrow [[Muammar Gaddafi]], the Libyan leader. In 2001, the group was added to a UN list of individuals and institutions "belonging to, or associated with, al-Qaeda".<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/1BA708B9-39ED-4B51-BED9-9B5322E75A8E.htm Zawahri: Libya group joins al-Qaeda] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308161906/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/1BA708B9-39ED-4B51-BED9-9B5322E75A8E.htm |date=2008-03-08 }} accessed November 3, 2007</ref>
[[Abdelhakim Belhadj]], a prominent rebel commander during the [[2011 Libyan civil war]], in an interview with the Italian newspaper [[Il Sole 24 Ore]] admit that many of his recruits had al-Qaeda links.<ref>{{cite news|last=Swami|first=Praveen|title=Libyan rebel commander admits his fighters have al-Qaeda links|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8407047/Libyan-rebel-commander-admits-his-fighters-have-al-Qaeda-links.html|accessdate=15 November 2011|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=2011-03-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111120025922/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8407047/Libyan-rebel-commander-admits-his-fighters-have-al-Qaeda-links.html|archive-date=2011-11-20|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> One of the major factions within the Libyan [[National Liberation Army (Libya)|National Liberation Army]] was the [[Libyan Islamic Movement]]. The group, formerly known as the Libyan Islamic Fighting Group, is well known to have had links to Maghreb faction of al-Qaeda.
On 1 November 2011, less than a month after the death of Muammar Gaddafi, the al-Qaeda flag was seen flying off the roof of a courthouse in Benghazi's city center.<ref>{{cite news|title=Al Qaeda flag flown above Benghazi courthouse|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8861608/Libya-Al-Qaeda-flag-flown-above-Benghazi-courthouse.html|work=Photos taken at: 7.00AM GMT 01 Nov 2011.|accessdate=15 November 2011|location=London|date=2011-11-01|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111115051312/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8861608/Libya-Al-Qaeda-flag-flown-above-Benghazi-courthouse.html|archive-date=2011-11-15|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
The extent of al-Qaeda's involvement is not yet known. Concerns have been voiced about what role [[MI6]] played in collaborating with the Libyan Islamic Movement.<ref>{{cite news|last=Birrell|first=Ian|title=MI6 role in Libyan rebels' rendition 'helped to strengthen al-Qaida|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/oct/24/mi6-libya-rebels-rendition-al-qaida|accessdate=15 November 2011|location=London|work=The Guardian|date=2011-10-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130828171609/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/oct/24/mi6-libya-rebels-rendition-al-qaida|archive-date=2013-08-28|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> The White House Deputy National Security Adviser [[John O. Brennan|John Brennan]] said "I'm concerned about what is going on inside of Libya because there's been a fair amount of disorder and upheaval in the country", "The weapons stock piles - whether we're talking about missile systems or we're talking about automatic weapons - these are things that we and our European allies are working very closely with the TNC [Transitional National Council] and Libyan authorities to get some control over. It's a big country, there were a lot of weapons depots that were scattered throughout the country and we're working again with the TNC and Europeans as well as the regional states. [...] (we are) very concerned about making sure that we do everything possible to prevent al-Qaeda from acquiring these weapons and threatening them.".<ref>{{cite news|last=Gardham|first=Duncan|title=Urgent efforts underway to recover stolen Libyan weapons from al-Qaeda|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/al-qaeda/8785093/Urgent-efforts-underway-to-recover-stolen-Libyan-weapons-from-al-Qaeda.html|accessdate=16 November 2011|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=2011-09-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111111184526/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/al-qaeda/8785093/Urgent-efforts-underway-to-recover-stolen-Libyan-weapons-from-al-Qaeda.html|archive-date=2011-11-11|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
==Somalia== {{main article|Al-Shabaab (militant group)}}
In February 2012, al-Shabaab officially pledged loyalty to Al-Qaeda. In an audio message to Al-Qaeda leader [[Ayman al-Zawahiri]], the al-Shabaab leader said: "On behalf of the soldiers and the commanders in al-Shabaab, we pledge allegiance to you. So lead us to the path of jihad and martyrdom that was drawn by our imam, the martyr Osama."<ref name=Joining>{{cite news|title=Al-Shabaab joining al Qaeda, monitor group says |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2012-02-09/africa/world_africa_somalia-shabaab-qaeda_1_al-zawahiri-qaeda-somali-americans?_s=PM:AFRICA |newspaper=CNN |date=9 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317152618/http://articles.cnn.com/2012-02-09/africa/world_africa_somalia-shabaab-qaeda_1_al-zawahiri-qaeda-somali-americans?_s=PM%3AAFRICA |archivedate=2012-03-17 |df= }}</ref>
Activities of al-Qaeda in Somalia are alleged to have begun as early as 1992.<ref name=EDITORIAL-SUDAN-RE-RUN-IN-SOMALIA>{{cite news |title=EDITORIAL: Sudan re-run in Somalia |publisher=Daily Times |url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2006%5C12%5C30%5Cstory_30-12-2006_pg3_1 |date=2006-12-30 |accessdate=2007-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930183453/http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2006%5C12%5C30%5Cstory_30-12-2006_pg3_1 |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }}</ref> The organization's role during the course of the 1992–1994 UN missions was limited to a handful of trainers. [[Ali Mohamed]] and other al-Qaeda members purportedly trained forces loyal to fraction leader [[Mohammed Farah Aidid]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Context of 'October 3–4, 1993' |url=http://www.cooperativeresearch.org/context.jsp?item=a100393mogadishu |publisher=Cooperative Research History Commons |accessdate=2007-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060528042138/http://www.cooperativeresearch.org/context.jsp?item=a100393mogadishu |archivedate=2006-05-28 |df= }}</ref> Osama bin Laden himself claimed in an interview with [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s [[John Miller (journalist)|John Miller]] to have sent al-Qaeda operatives to Somalia. One of the al-Qaeda fighters present during the interview claimed to have personally slit the throats of three American soldiers in Somalia.<ref name=GREETINGS-AMERICA-MY-NAME-IS-OSAMA-BIN-LADEN>{{cite news |title = Greetings America, My Name is Osama bin Laden |url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/binladen/who/miller.html |date = 1999-02-01 |publisher = [[Esquire Magazine]] |accessdate = 2007-01-08 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070228044618/http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/binladen/who/miller.html |archive-date = 2007-02-28 |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref> [[Mark Bowden]], author of ''[[Black Hawk Down (book)|Black Hawk Down]]'', states the terrorist organization did train some of Aidid's men, but they were not personally part of the fight with US forces in the [[Battle of Mogadishu (1993)|1993 battle of Mogadishu]].<ref name=THE-TRUTH-ABOUT-MOGADISHU>{{cite news |title = The truth about Mogadishu |url = http://www.philly.com/mld/philly/living/people/women/15703906.htm |publisher = [[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |date = 2006-10-08 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160517100255/http://articles.philly.com/2006-10-08/news/25417846_1_al-qaeda-mogadishu-bin |archivedate = 2016-05-17 |accessdate = 2017-07-14 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref>
Al-Qaeda was also linked to militant [[Islamic Courts Union]] (ICU) front in Somalia. It is believed several terrorist attacks were orchestrated from [[Ras Kamboni]], in the extreme southern tip of Somalia adjacent to Kenya, including the 1998 United States embassy bombings and the 2002 Mombasa hotel bombing.<ref>Abdi Abdi, [http://www.ena.gov.et/Link/The%20Talibanisation%20of%20Somalia.asp "The Talibanisation of Somalia"]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''Ethiopian News Agency'', 12 July 2006</ref> On June 22, 2006, [[Assistant Secretary for the Bureau of African Affairs|Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs]] [[Jendayi Frazer]] announced the U.S. was seeking the assistance of the ICU in the apprehension of suspects who carried out attacks against its East African embassies and a hotel in Kenya. She listed the following persons as suspected of being in Somalia (name and nationality): [[Fazul Abdullah Mohamed]] (Comoros), [[Saleh Ali Saleh Nabhan]] (Kenya), and [[Abu Taha al-Sudan]] (Sudan). When the ICU did not cooperate, the U.S. first financed the rival factions, and then followed with limited air strikes as the ICU rule in Mogadishu fell in the face of [[Ethiopian Army]] assault. The Pentagon said a high level al-Qaeda member from the ICU was captured in Somalia and transferred to the U.S. military prison in Guantanamo Bay.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6729015.stm |title=Pentagon captures high level Al-Qaeda member in Somalia |access-date=2008-09-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080412111551/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6729015.stm |archive-date=2008-04-12 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.knx1070.com/pages/551987.php?contentType=4&contentId=584302 U.S. detains Al-Qaeda member] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928063121/http://www.knx1070.com/pages/551987.php?contentType=4&contentId=584302 |date=2007-09-28 }}</ref>
After the dissolution of the ICU, Al-Qaeda reportedly established strong ties with the [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|Al-Shabaab]] splinter group.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8491329.stm |title=Somali Islamists al-Shabab 'join al-Qaeda fight' |access-date=2012-01-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213005742/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8491329.stm |archive-date=2010-02-13 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
In September 2009, it is thought that the [[Saleh Ali Saleh Nabhan]] was killed during a military raid in Somalia. He was a top Al-Qaeda suspect and was thought to be responsible for attacks on a hotel in Kenya and on an [[Israel]]i airliner in 2002.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8254957.stm BBC news – Al-Qaeda Somalia suspect 'killed']</ref><ref>[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1251804570732&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull JPost – Kenya terrorist killed in Somalia raid]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Sudan== In 1991, [[Sudan]]'s [[National Islamic Front]], an Islamist group that had recently gained power, invited al-Qaeda to move operations to Sudan.<ref name=TESTIMONY-OF-JT-CARUSO>{{cite web |title=Testimony of J. T. Caruso, Acting Assistant Director, CounterTerrorism Division, FBI Before the Subcommittee on International Operations and Terrorism, Committee on Foreign Relations, United States Senate – December 18, 2001 – "Al-Qaeda International" |url=https://www.fbi.gov/congress/congress01/caruso121801.htm |date=2001-12-18 |publisher=[[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] |accessdate=2007-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070110035127/http://www.fbi.gov/congress/congress01/caruso121801.htm |archivedate=2007-01-10 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> For several years, al-Qaeda operated several businesses (including import/export, farm, and construction firms) in what might be considered a period of financial consolidation. The group built a major 1200-km (845-mi) highway connecting the capital [[Khartoum]] with [[Port Sudan]].<ref name=INSIDE-AL-QAEDA>{{cite web |title= Inside Al-Qaeda |url=http://www.mideastweb.org/alqaeda.htm |accessdate=2007-01-18| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070109181044/http://www.mideastweb.org/alqaeda.htm| archivedate= 9 January 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> However, they also ran a number of camps where they trained operatives in the use of firearms and explosives.
In 1996, Osama bin Laden was asked to leave Sudan after the United States put the regime under extreme pressure to expel him, citing possible connections to the 1994 attempted assassination of [[Egypt]]ian President [[Hosni Mubarak]] while his motorcade was in [[Addis Ababa, Ethiopia]]. Controversy exists regarding whether Sudan offered to turn bin Laden over to the U.S. prior to the expulsion. There is an audio tape ([https://web.archive.org/web/20070808205904/http://www.newsmax.com/audio/BILLVH.mp3 Audio]) ([http://www.newsmax.com/archives/ic/2006/9/10/181819.shtml?s=ic Transcript]) recording of former President Bill Clinton talking about the offer from the Sudanese government. There are conflicting reports on whether the Sudanese government indeed made such an offer, but they were in fact prepared to turn him over to Saudi Arabia, who declined to take him.<ref>"Newsmax" http://www.newsmax.com/archives/ic/2006/9/10/181819.shtml?s=ic {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070820193956/http://newsmax.com/archives/ic/2006/9/10/181819.shtml?s=ic |date=2007-08-20 }}</ref>
Osama bin Laden finally left Sudan in a well-executed operation, arriving at [[Jalalabad, Afghanistan]] by air in late 1996 with over 200 of his supporters and their families.
==See also== * [[Al-Qaeda involvement in the Middle East]] * [[Al-Qaeda involvement in Europe]]

page.title: Albuquerque Air Route Traffic Control Center

revision.comment: /* Ultra High Altitude Sectors */
revision.text:
'''Albuquerque Air Route Traffic Control Center''' ('''ZAB''') is located at 8000 Louisiana Boulevard, [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque]], [[New Mexico]], [[United States]]. The Albuquerque [[ARTCC]] is one of 22 Air Route Traffic Control Centers in the United States.
The primary responsibility is the separation of overflights, and the expedited sequencing of arrivals and departures along STARs ([[Standard Terminal Arrival Route]]s) and SIDs ([[Standard Instrument Departure]]s) for the airspace over most of Arizona and New Mexico, as well as parts of California, Colorado, Oklahoma, and Texas.
ZAB covers an area that includes one ''[[Class B Airports|class Bravo]]'' airport. * [[Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport]] (PHX) in [[Phoenix, AZ]]
ZAB also includes four ''[[Class C airport|class Charlie]]'' airports. * [[Albuquerque International Sunport]] (ABQ) in [[Albuquerque, NM]] * [[El Paso International Airport]] (ELP) in [[El Paso, TX]] * [[Rick Husband Amarillo International Airport]] (AMA) in [[Amarillo, TX]] * [[Tucson International Airport]] (TUS) in [[Tucson, AZ]]
== Control location == {{Geographic Location |Centre = Albuquerque ARTCC |North = Denver ARTCC |Northeast = Kansas City ARTCC |East = [[Fort Worth Air Route Traffic Control Center|Fort Worth ARTCC]] |Southeast = [[Houston Air Route Traffic Control Center|Houston ARTCC]] |South = Monterrey FIR, Mexico |Southwest = Mazatlan FIR, Mexico |West = [[Los Angeles Air Route Traffic Control Center|Los Angeles ARTCC]] }}
== Subdivision == ZAB's airspace is divided both geographically and altitudinally.
ZAB's primary subdivisions are known as specialties. There are five different specialties known as the North, East, Southeast, Southwest and Northwest. Each specialty is broken down further into 7 or 8 sectors.
By altitude, ZAB comprises 7 ultra-high sectors, 16 high-altitude sectors, 13 low-altitude sectors, and 3 low-high sectors. The vertical strata of these sectors vary greatly depending on the geographic location covered and the variety of traffic the controllers work.
=== North specialty===
==== Ultra High Altitude Sectors ==== * BLR 58 (Black Rock Ultra High) - 126.<ref>"OU" - worked 33-1/2 yrs ZAB North Specialty- retired 7-1-2016</ref> 92
==== High Altitude Sectors ==== * ABQ 68 (Albuquerque) - 134.6 * TAN 79 (TANER) - 118.65 * GUP 93 (Gallup) - 120.55
==== Low Altitude Sectors ==== * SAN 16 (Sandia) - 132.8 * LAV 17 (Lavan) - 124.32
==== Low-High Altitude Sectors ==== * CNX 94 (Corona) - 133.65
=== East specialty ===
==== Ultra High Altitude Sectors ==== * CIM 72 (Cimarron 72) - 128.22 * TCC 96 (Tucumcari 96) - 128.67 * DHT 98 (Dalhart 98) - 132.12
==== High Altitude Sectors ==== * TAN 70 (TANER Hi) - 120.95 * KEN 71 (KENTO Hi) - 133.05 * LVS 95 (Las Vegas Hi) - 125.07 * AMA 97 (Amarillo Hi) - 134.75
==== Low Altitude Sectors ==== * AMA 15 (Amarillo Lo) - 127.85 * ROW 12 (Roswell Lo) - 132.65 * TCC 11 (Tucumcari Lo) - 126.85
=== Southeast specialty ===
==== Ultra High Altitude Sectors ==== * FST 78 (Fort Stockton 78) - 133.22
==== High Altitude Sectors ==== * ELP 63 (El Paso 63) - 120.97 * TXO 87 (Texico 87) - 132.32 * SUN 89 (Sunland 89) - 125.52
==== Low Altitude Sectors ==== * DMN 19 (Deming 19) - 128.2 * SFL 20 (Salt Flat 20) - 135.87 * CVS 21 (Cannon 21) - 126.85
==== Low-High Altitude Sectors ==== * ROW 23 (Roswell 23) - 132.65
=== Southwest ===
==== Ultra High Altitude Sectors ==== * PHX 65 (65) - 132.45 * NOCHI 80 (80) - 126.22
==== High Altitude Sectors ==== * SSO 90 (San Simon 90) - 133.0 * GBN 91 (Gila Bend 91) - 135.15
==== Low Altitude Sectors ==== * GBN 42 (Gila Bend 42) - 126.45 * TUS 46 (Tucson 46) - 125.4 * SVC 47 (Silver City 47) - 134.45 * BXK 49 (Buckeye 49) - 125.25
=== Northwest specialty ===
==== High Altitude Sectors ==== * HIP 37 (HIPPI 37) - 134.32 * PAY 50 (PAYSO 50) - 128.12 * INW 67 (Winslow 67) - 133.92 * PRC 92 (Prescott 92) - 135.32
==== Low Altitude Sectors ==== * FOS 39 (FOSIL 39) - 135.72 * DRK 43 (Drake 43) - 128.45 * INW 45 (Winslow 45) - 127.67
==== Low-High Altitude Sectors ==== * MIA 38 (Miami 38) - 132.9
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.srh.noaa.gov/zab/ Albuquerque Center Weather Service Unit (CWSU)] ([[National Weather Service|NWS]]/[[Federal Aviation Administration|FAA]])

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=November 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox organization | image = | alt = | caption = | formation = {{Start date and age|1965|df=y}} | type = | purpose = Primary organ of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]] | headquarters = [[Marlborough House]]
[[London]], {{postcode|SW|1}} | coords = | leader_title = [[Commonwealth Secretary-General|Secretary-General]] | leader_name = [[Patricia Scotland]] (2016–present) | name = Commonwealth Secretariat | image_size = | abbreviation = | location = | membership = | membership_year = | parent_organisation = Commonwealth of Nations | website = {{URL|http://www.thecommonwealth.org/}} }} The '''Commonwealth Secretariat''' is the main intergovernmental agency and central institution of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]]. It is responsible for facilitating co-operation between members; organising meetings, including the [[Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting]]s (CHOGM); assisting and advising on policy development; and providing assistance to countries in implementing the decisions and policies of the Commonwealth.{{cite web |url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/subhomepage/151087/ |title=Commonwealth Secretariat |accessdate=27 July 2007 |publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819010932/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/subhomepage/151087/ |archivedate=19 August 2007 |df=dmy-all }} The Secretariat has [[United Nations General Assembly observers|observer]] status in the [[United Nations General Assembly]]. It is located at [[Marlborough House]] in London, the United Kingdom, a former royal residence that was given by [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]], [[Head of the Commonwealth]]. ==History== [[File:Marlborough House.jpg|thumb|[[Marlborough House]], London, the headquarters of the Commonwealth Secretariat, the Commonwealth's principal intergovernmental institution]] The Secretariat was established by Heads of Government in 1965, taking over many of the functions of the United Kingdom Government's [[Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations|Commonwealth Relations Office]], as part of a major shake-up of the organisation of the Commonwealth. At the same time, the United Kingdom succeeded in advocating the creation of the Secretariat's sister organisation, the [[Commonwealth Foundation]] was founded to foster non-governmental relations and the promotion of the [[Commonwealth Family]] network of civil societies.{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/40203725 |last=McIntyre |first=W. David |authorlink=W. David McIntyre |date=October 1998 |title=Canada and the creation of the Commonwealth Secretariat |jstor=40203725 |journal=International Journal |volume=53 |issue=4 |pages=753–777 }} Other attempts by members to create similar central bodies, such as a medical conference (proposed by [[New Zealand]]), a development bank ([[Jamaica]]), and an institution for satellite communications (Canada) failed. The creation of the Secretariat itself was a contentious issue. The United Kingdom and other long-established countries had hoped to slow the tide of expansion of Commonwealth membership to prevent the dilution of their traditional power within the Commonwealth (particularly after the admission of [[Cyprus]]). This may have involved a dual-tiered Commonwealth, requiring the continuation of the organisation of Commonwealth co-operation by meetings, rather than a central administration. However, the new African members were keener to create an independent inter-governmental 'central clearing house' (as [[Ghana]]'s [[Kwame Nkrumah]] described it) to remove power from the older dominions. [[Milton Obote]] of [[Uganda]] was the first to propose a specifically titled 'secretariat', which was then formally proposed by [[Eric Williams]] of [[Trinidad and Tobago]], who wished to see it based upon the secretariats of the [[Organization of American States|OAS]], [[European Economic Community|EEC]], and [[Organisation of African Unity|OAU]]. Earlier attempts at the formation of a central secretariat had been made and failed. Australia had proposed the establishment four times (in 1907, 1924, 1932, and 1944), whilst [[New Zealand]] had also made proposals in 1909 and 1956. ==Staff== The chief executive of the Secretariat, and of the Commonwealth as a whole, is the [[Commonwealth Secretary-General]].{{cite news |first= |last= |title=Profile: The Commonwealth |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/country_profiles/1554175.stm |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=16 June 2008 }} All Secretariat staff report to the secretary-general, who is also responsible for spending the Secretariat's budget, which is granted by the [[Commonwealth Heads of Government|Heads of Government]]. It is the secretary-general, and not the ceremonial [[Head of the Commonwealth]], that represents the Commonwealth publicly. The secretary-general is elected by the Heads of Government at the [[Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting]]s for terms of four years; previously, until 2000, a term was five years. The current Secretary-General is Dominica's [[Patricia Scotland, Baroness Scotland of Asthal|Patricia Scotland]], who replaced [[Kamalesh Sharma]] as Secretary-General on 1 April 2016.{{cite web|url=http://thecommonwealth.org/media/news/together-we-are-so-much-stronger-says-scotland-her-first-day-new-secretary-general|title=‘Together we are so much stronger’ says Scotland as she becomes new Secretary-General|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|accessdate=1 April 2016}} The secretary-general is assisted by three [[Commonwealth Deputy Secretary-General|deputy secretaries-general]]: one responsible for economic affairs (currently Deodat Maharaj), one for political affairs (Josephine Ojiambo), and one for corporate affairs (Gary Dunn). The secretary-general may appoint junior staff at his own discretion, provided the Secretariat can afford it, whilst the more senior staff may be appointed only from a shortlist of nominations from the Heads of Government.{{cite journal |last=Doxey |first=Margaret |date=January 1979 |title=The Commonwealth Secretary-General: Limits of Leadership |journal=[[International Affairs (journal)|International Affairs]] |volume=55 |issue=1 |pages=67–83 |doi=10.2307/2617133}} In practice, the secretary-general has more power than this; member governments consult the secretary-general on nominations, and the secretary-general has also at times submitted nominations of his own. All members of staff are exempt from [[Income tax in the United Kingdom|income tax]], under the [[International Organisations Act 2005]], which redefined the legal status of the Secretariat. ==Headquarters== The Secretariat is headquartered at [[Marlborough House]], in London, the United Kingdom.{{cite web |url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/Internal/34467/151305/marlborough_house_history/ |title=The History of Marlborough House |accessdate=16 June 2008 |publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624014156/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/Internal/34467/151305/marlborough_house_history/ |archivedate=24 June 2008 |df=dmy-all }} Marlborough House is located on [[Pall Mall, London|Pall Mall]], [[City of Westminster|Westminster]], next to [[St. James's Palace]], which is formally the location of the British [[Court of St. James's|Royal Court]]. Marlborough House was previously a royal residence in its own right, but was given by [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]], the [[Head of the Commonwealth]], to the British government in September 1959 for use for Commonwealth purposes. This was first realised three years later. Another three years later, in 1965, the building passed to the Secretariat upon its foundation. The building itself was designed by [[Sir Christopher Wren]] and served as the London residence of the [[dukes of Marlborough]] until it was given to [[Princess Charlotte Augusta of Wales|Princess Charlotte]] in 1817. The [[Commonwealth Secretariat Act 1966]], which applied retroactively from the establishment of the Secretariat in 1965, first granted the organisation full [[diplomatic immunity]]. This has been subjected to a number of lawsuits challenging this, including ''Mohsin v Commonwealth Secretariat'', and in 2005, ''[[Sumukan Limited v Commonwealth Secretariat]]''. The 1966 Act had been interpreted by [[England and Wales|English]] courts as allowing the courts to exercise supervisory jurisdiction under the [[Arbitration Act 1996]] over the Commonwealth's arbitration tribunal, which had been envisaged as the sole organ to arbitrate on matters related to the Secretariat's operations in the United Kingdom.{{cite web |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200405/cmbills/069/en/05069x--.htm |title=International Organisations Bill |accessdate=16 June 2008 |publisher=[[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] }} In light of this interpretation, the Commonwealth Secretariat Act was amended by the [[International Organisations Act 2005]], which gave the Commonwealth Secretariat Arbitral Tribunal the same legal immunity as the Secretariat itself, guaranteeing independence of the English courts. ==See also== * [[Commonwealth Foundation]] * [[Commonwealth Youth Programme]] ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.thecommonwealth.org/ Commonwealth Secretariat official website] {{Commonwealth of Nations topics}} [[Category:Commonwealth Secretariat| ]] [[Category:1965 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Institutions of the Commonwealth of Nations|Secretariat]] [[Category:International organisations based in London]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1965]] [[Category:Secretariats of international organisations|Commonwealth]] [[Category:United Nations General Assembly observers]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox university | name = International Institute for Asian Studies (IIAS) | image_name = IIAS_logo_red.png | motto = Encouraging knowledge and enhancing the study of Asia | established = 1993 | city = [[Leiden]] | country = [[Netherlands]] | head_label = Director | head = Philippe Peycam | website = [https://www.iias.asia/ www.iias.asia] }}
The '''International Institute for Asian Studies''' ('''IIAS''') is a global research institute and knowledge exchange platform, based in Leiden, the Netherlands. The Institute initiates and promotes interdisciplinary and trans-sectoral programmes that engage partners in Asia as well as institutes elsewhere in the world. So doing, the Institute aims to promote a more integrated understanding of present-day Asian realities as well as to pioneer new approaches to Asian Studies in a changing global context, and, more specifically, to contribute to new humanistically-informed and policy-relevant knowledge about Asia.
==Establishment== The International Institute for Asian Studies was established in 1993, following recommendations by two successive committees, installed by the Dutch Ministry of Education and Science (1989) and the Royal Netherlands Institute for Arts and Sciences (KNAW).<ref>Advisory Committee on the ‘Small Arts’ departments (Dutch: ''Kleine Letteren'') chaired by J.F. Staal, set up in July 1989 by the Minister of Education and Science. Report: 'Krishna in the Delta' (October 1991).</ref>
The city of Leiden was only a logical choice for the Institute’s headquarters. Leiden is home to many institutes with expertise and resources about Asia, including Leiden University, the Royal Netherlands Institute of Southeast Asian and Caribbean Studies (KITLV), the Siebold House Japanmuseum, the Netherlands Institute for the Near East (NINO), the National Museum of Ethnology and the National Museum of Antiquities.
The International Institute for Asian Studies was, and still is, hosted by Leiden University, which provides office space as well as administrative and IT services. From 1997 to 2012, IIAS also had a branch office in Amsterdam, facilitated by the University of Amsterdam<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://iias.asia/iiasn/13/Institutes/13eaxb08.html|title=The IIAS Branch Office in Amsterdam, IIAS Newsletter 13, Summer 1997.|last=Rutten|first=Mario|date=|website=iias.asia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-25}}</ref>.
IIAS receives its core funding from the Ministry of Education. The Institute additionally generates income from external sources, via grants, subsidies, and the joint execution of programmes.
While upholding its original mission, the Institute has over the years adapted and expanded its programmatic agenda in response to the demands of a changing global context.
==Activities== Activities include multi-year research programmes and the building of academic networks, the organisation of international conferences and roundtables, a fellowship and a publication programme, PhD in-situ masterclasses, and the publication of a free periodical on Asian Studies (titled, ''[https://iias.asia/the-newsletter/ The Newsletter]'').
The following current programmes and networks are among the Institute's main initiatives:
* [https://iias.asia/research/urban-knowledge-network-asia-ukna Urban Knowledge Network Asia (UKNA)] * [https://ukna.asia/seannet Southeast Asia Neighborhoods Network (SEANNET)] * [https://iias.asia/hab Humanities across Borders: Asia-Africa in the World] * [https://africasia.org/ Asia-Africa, A new Axis of Knowledge] * [https://iias.asia/research/leiden-centre-indian-ocean-studies Leiden Centre for the Indian Ocean Studies] * [https://icas.asia/ International Convention of Asia Scholars (ICAS)] * [https://asiascholars.eu/ European Alliance for Asian Studies] *[https://iias.asia/critical-heritage-studies Critical Heritage Studies of Asia and Europe]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== *https://www.iias.asia
{{coord missing|Netherlands}}
[[Category:Asian studies]] [[Category:Research institutes in the Netherlands]]

revision.comment: "followings" -> "following", "heir" -> "their"
revision.text:
{{ethnic group| |group=Khmuic |image=[[Image:Khmu children in Laos.JPG|220px]] |caption=Khmu children in [[Laos]] |population=643,000
(excluding disputed [[Khao people|Khao]] and [[Bit people|Bit]] peoples) |popplace=[[Laos]], [[Vietnam]], [[Thailand]], [[Burma]] and [[China]] |rels=[[Theravada Buddhism]] [[Animism]], [[Shamanism]], [[Ancestor worship|Native Ancestral Worship]] |langs=[[Khmuic languages]] |related=[[Palaungic languages|Palaungic peoples]], [[Mon–Khmer languages|Mon–Khmer peoples]] and [[Munda languages|Munda peoples]] }} '''Khmuic peoples''' refers to a group of [[ethnic groups]] of [[Southeast Asia]]. ==Geographic distribution== The Khmuic peoples are aboriginal to Laos and surrounding areas. Most Khmuic peoples live in northern [[Laos]] and neighboring areas in [[Vietnam]], although they can also be found in [[Thailand]], [[Burma]] and [[China]]. ==Individual Khmuic speaking groups== The individual Khmuic ethnic groups are as follows: *[[Khmu people|Khmu]] *[[Khmu people|Khmu U]] *[[Khmu people|Khmu Rok]] *[[Khmu people|Khmu Kwean]] *[[Khmu people|Khmu Cheuang]] *[[Khmu people|Khmu Leu]] *[[Khmu people|Khmu Yuan]] *[[Khmu people|Khmu Khrong]] *[[Khmu people|Khmu Kasak]] *[[Khmu people|Khmu Mea]] Other two groups: [[Khmu Chuang people|Khmu Chuang]] and [[Khmu Kaye people|Khmu Kaye]] are extinct or were assimilated in other ethnic groups especially Khmu Chuang was believed to be extinct, absorbed or assimilated by or into Khmer. In the ancient time, the Khmu Chuang lived in the southern part of Khmuic territory which is the area of the present day southern Laos). The Khmu Kaye lived in the eastern part of Khmuic territory which is the area of the present day Xiengkhuang province. Be in mind that some scholars confuse Khmu Cheuang [cɯaŋ] and Khmu Chuang [cuaŋ]. These two groups are not the same, Khmu Cheuang are still exist in the present day and mostly live in northwestern of Vietnam. ==Non-Khmu peoples== The following are individual ethnic groups which some scholars misunderstand that they are Khmu and speak Khmuic. In fact they are much different from Khmu, in both language and culture. There are only a few words (less than 10%) of their vocabularies that resemble Khmuic. *[[Lua people|Lua]] *[[Mal people|Mal]] (also known as the ''Tin'' in Thailand and the ''Thin'' in Laos) *[[Mlabri people|Mlabri]] (also known as the ''Yumbri'') *[[O Du people|O Du]] *[[Phai people|Phai]] *[[Pray people|Pray]] *[[Xinh Mul people|Xinh Mul]] *[[Phong people|Phong]] *[[Phong-Kniang people|Phong-Kniang]] *[[Khang people|Khang]] There are also the [[Khao people|Khao]] and [[Bit people|Bit]] peoples which were once thought to be Khmuic, although recent linguistic studies suggest they are probably [[Palaungic languages|Palaungic]]. ==Origin== {{see also|Peopling of Laos}} The Khmuic peoples are believed to have migrated by land from China to Laos, where they have resided for at least 4,000 years. Some 10,000 years ago, they were probably part of a largely homogenous ethnicity, now referred to as the [[Austro-Asiatic languages|Austro-Asiatic peoples]], with a homeland somewhere within the borders of the modern-day [[People's Republic of China]]. The prevalence of [[Haplogroup O (Y-DNA)|Y-DNA Haplogroup O]] among Austro-Asiatic peoples suggests a common ancestry with the [[Sino-Tibetan languages|Sino-Tibetan]], [[Austronesian people|Austronesian]], and [[Hmong–Mien languages|Hmong–Mien]] peoples some 35,000 years ago in China. Haplogroup O is a [[subclade]] of [[Haplogroup K (Y-DNA)|Y-DNA Haplogroup K]], which is believed to have originated approximately 40,000 years ago somewhere between Iran and Central China. In addition to the ethnicities previously mentioned, the progenitor of Haplogroup K was the patrilineal ancestor of nearly all modern [[Melanesians]] and [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]]. Haplogroup K, in turn, is a subclade of [[Haplogroup F (Y-DNA)|Y-DNA Haplogroup F]], which is believed to have originated in Northern Africa some 45,000 years ago. In addition to the ethnicities previously mentioned, the progenitor of Haplogroup F was probably the ancestor of all [[Indo-European languages|Indo-Europeans]]. ==Language== Their languages belong to the [[Khmuic languages|Khmuic]] language family, which is a branch of the [[Austro-Asiatic languages|Austro-Asiatic]] language family. Most scholars agree that the Khmuic languages are part of the [[Mon–Khmer languages|Mon–Khmer]] branch of the Austro-Asiatic family, but the validity of the Mon–Khmer branch has recently been called into question.{{cite book|last=Sidwell|first=Paul|title=Classifying the Austroasiatic languages: history and state of the art|year=2009|publisher=Lincom Europa|location=Munich|authorlink=Paul Sidwell}} ==Society== The Khmuic are generally an agricultural people, although gathering, hunting, trapping and fishing are also parts of the Khmuic lifestyle.[http://www.infomekong.com/khmu.htm Khmu Profile] ==References== == External links == * http://projekt.ht.lu.se/rwaai RWAAI (Repository and Workspace for Austroasiatic Intangible Heritage) * [[hdl:10050/00-0000-0000-0003-66E8-9@view|http://hdl.handle.net/10050/00-0000-0000-0003-66E8-9@view]] Khmuic languages in RWAAI Digital Archive {{Ethnic groups in Vietnam}} {{Ethnic groups in Thailand}} {{Ethnic groups in Burma}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Laos]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in China]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Myanmar]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Vietnam]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Thailand]] [[Category:Khmuic peoples| ]] {{Asia-ethno-group-stub}}

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox political party | name = National Union of Workers |native_name = {{lang|ta|தொழிலாளர் தேசிய சங்கம்}}
{{lang|si|කම්කරු ජාතික සංගමය}} |colorcode = Green |leader = [[Palani Digambaran]] |chairperson = |president = |secretary_general = |leader1_title = Founding Member |leader1_name = V. K. Vellayan |leader2_title = General Secretary |leader2_name = S. Philip |leader3_title= = Financial Secretary |leader3_name = J.M.Sebastian |slogan = | founded = {{plainlist| *V.K.Veellayan (1965.05.01) *C.V.Veluppillai }} |dissolved = |merger = |split = |predecessor = |merged = |successor = |headquarters = 187, Dimbulla Road, Hatton |newspaper = |student_wing = |youth_wing = |membership_year = |membership = |national = |international = |seats1_title = |seats1 = |symbol = |flag = |country = Sri Lanka | affiliation = | current = | merged_into = |website = | footnotes = }} The '''National Union of Workers''' ('''NUW''') ( {{lang-ta|தொழிலாளர் தேசிய சங்கம்|translit=Toḻilāḷar Tēciya Caṅkam}}; {{lang-si|කම්කරු ජාතික සංගමය|translit=Kamkaru Jātika Saṁgamaya}}) is an active [[trade union]] in the [[tea]] plantations in [[Sri Lanka]]. The NUW was established in 1965 by V. K. Vellayan, his colleague with the most effective [[Labor force|labour force]] in the tea plantation in Sri Lanka. Earlier ages of NUW V.K. Vellayan known as peoples leader and commonly VK. He make leaders of the NUW as a labourer of tea estates and also members of the NUW. VK made enthusiastic leadership corrector such as Aiyadorai known as mattalai Rohini, Perumal, and Punniya Moorthi. These leaders are gained from estates and VK thought them trade union politice, Leadership and Management and made them as successor in trade union politics in upcountry. In age of VK's period the NUW gain as leading trade union in Sri Lanka and it had nearly five hundred thousand of member and marched historical labour revolution in the tea plantations in Sri Lanka. VK identified that the Employment provident fund (EPF) is different from the service gratuity. He note this point to the Labour Department and filed a case at supreme court and he won for the voices of laborers. Aftermath VK's era the NUW fallen it decrees of members. In this time p. Thigambaram elected as President of this Trade Union. He selected for Central Provincial Council from Nuwaraeliya District with Vice Leader M. Udayakumar. In 2010 parliamentary elections, P. Thigambaram selected for Parliament of Sri Lanka for Nuwaraeliya District. Later in 2015 General Election Mr. P Thigambaram selected to the Parliament with absolute majority in Nuwaraeliya District with M. Thilakarajah who is known as a poet and social activist in Malayagam (Sri Lankan Hill Country). This victory made P. Thigambaram as a Cabinet Minister in Sri Lanka and his voice for the Plantation community is highly appreciated by the youths and social activist. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Trade unions in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Tamil Progressive Alliance]] [[Category:Tamil political parties in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Political parties in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1965]] [[Category:1965 establishments in Ceylon]] {{-}} {{Sri Lankan political parties}} {{Asia-trade-union-stub}} {{SriLanka-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} "No Dream Impossible" | image = [[File:Lindsay - No Dream Impossible.jpg|200px]] | caption = | year = 2001 | country = United Kingdom | artist = [[Lindsay Dracass]] | as = | with = | language = English | languages = | composer = [[Russ Ballard]], Chris Winter | lyricist = [[Russ Ballard]], Chris Winter | place = 15th | points = 28 | prev = Don't Play That Song Again | prev_link = Don't Play That Song Again | next = Come Back | next_link = Come Back (Jessica Garlick song) }} '''"No Dream Impossible"''' was the [[United Kingdom]] entry for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2001]], written by [[Russ Ballard]] and Chris Winter and performed by [[Lindsay Dracass]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/79841/chart-beat-bonus |title=Chart Beat Bonus |publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine) |Billboard]]'' |date= |accessdate=2017-07-24}} The song was performed 16th on the night of the contest, following [[Turkey]]'s [[Sedat Yüce]] with "[[Sevgiliye son]]" and preceding [[Slovenia]]'s [[Nuša Derenda]] with "[[Energy (Nuša Derenda song)|Energy]]". The song received 28 points, placing 15th in a field of 23. The song, which reached No. 32 on the [[UK Singles Chart]],{{cite web |url = http://www.theofficialcharts.com/search-results-album/_/No+Dream+Impossible#single |title = Chart Archive - Lindsay - No Dream Impossible |website = Theofficialcharts.com |accessdate = 2012-05-31 }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} was succeeded as UK entry at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2002|2002 contest]] by [[Jessica Garlick]] with "[[Come Back (Jessica Garlick song)|Come Back]]". ==Charts== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !Chart (2001) ! style="text-align:center;"|Peak
position |- |UK Singles [[Official Charts Company]] | style="text-align:center;"|32 |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before="[[Don't Play That Song Again]]"
by [[Nicki French]]| title=[[United Kingdom in the Eurovision Song Contest]] | years=[[United Kingdom in the Eurovision Song Contest 2001|2001]] | after="[[Come Back (Jessica Garlick song)|Come Back]]"
by [[Jessica Garlick]] | }} {{end}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 2001}} {{Eurovision (UK)}} [[Category:2001 songs]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 2001]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Songs written by Russ Ballard]] {{UK-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox radio station | name = Paris-Mondial | image = | image_size = <!-- optional when used with image parameter, specifies image size --> | alt = <!-- optional when used with image parameter, specifies image alternate (alt) text --> | caption = <!-- optional when used with image parameter, specifies image caption --> | city = | area = | branding = | slogan = | frequency = <!-- {{Frequency|NNN|XHz}} --> | translator = | repeater = | airdate = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | last airdate = <!-- for defunct stations --> | share = | share as of = | share source = | format = Variety | language = [[Multilingual]] | power = | erp = | haat = | class = | facility_id = | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|}} --> | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = | former_frequencies = | affiliations = | operator = | owner = [[French Republic]] | licensee = | sister_stations = | webcast = <!-- [URL Listen Live] --> | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }}
'''Paris-Mondial''' (later known as '''Voice of France''') was a [[France|French]]-government-owned [[shortwave]] [[external service]] radio station that began broadcasting in 1937. After the [[fall of France]], it continued broadcasting a domestic-only program.
==Origins== Paris-Mondial first broadcast in 1937, targeting an international audience with multilingual programming. Its sign-on for its U.S.-directed broadcasts was "Hello, America!". A 1938 survey of French embassies reported that Paris-Mondial enjoyed a clear signal in [[North America]], though reception in [[Africa]] and the [[Caribbean]] was spotty.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Scales|first1=Rebecca|title=Radio and the Politics of Sound in Interwar France, 1921–1939|date=2015|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=1107108675|page=261|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wxl-CwAAQBAJ&dq}}</ref>
==Second World War== [[File:Tony Aubin 1930.jpg|thumb|Tony Aubin, artistic director of Paris-Mondial]] Following the [[Battle of France|invasion of France]] in 1940, Paris-Mondial eliminated all non-English programming and began a non-stop schedule of broadcasts that included, ultimately fruitless, appeals for help by Frenchmen who had lived or worked in the [[United States]].<ref name="war"/>
On June 9, 1940, the staff of Paris-Mondial abandoned their facilities in [[Paris]] and evacuated to a series of backup facilities, first in [[Poitiers]] and, after that became untenable, to [[Bordeaux]].<ref name="war"/><ref name="keane"/> As of June 12, the monitoring centers of the U.S. networks [[NBC]] and [[CBS]] reported the station was continuing to transmit its "usual newscasts" and could still be picked-up in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Today's Radio Programs|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/12521245/|accessdate=February 28, 2017|work=The Daily Mail|page=9|date=June 12, 1940}} {{subscription required}}</ref> However, this routine soon gave way to "recordings of military marches and panicked appeals for guns, tanks, and planes".<ref name="keane"/> On June 14 the station went off-air, returning on June 15 with the sign-on "this is Paris-Mondial, broadcasting from somewhere in France". Programming became increasingly intermittent during the final days of the [[French Third Republic]].<ref name="keane">{{cite book|author=Keane, Damien.|title=Ireland and the Problem of Information: Irish Writing, Radio, Late Modernist Communication.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-L0tCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT120|year=2014|publisher=Penn State University Press|location=Pennsylvania|isbn=978-0-271-06756-8|pages=120–121}}</ref> In its last hours, the station's broadcasts consisted almost exclusively of frantic [[Talk radio|talk]]-format programs "begging for aid".<ref name="war">{{cite book|last1=Graves|first1=Harold|title=War On The Short Wave|date=1941|publisher=Foreign Policy Association|page=20|url=https://archive.org/stream/WarOnTheShortWave#page/n21/mode/2up}}</ref>
After the fall of France, Paris-Mondial was rebranded by the government of the [[Vichy France|État Français]] as "the Voice of France" and aired a mixture of original programming and rebroadcasts of German radio, all internally directed (under the terms of the French surrender, international broadcasting was prohibited). When broadcasting German programming, Voice of France operated under the name "Y".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Berg|first1=Jerome|title=On the Short Waves, 1923–1945: Broadcast Listening in the Pioneer Days of Radio|date=1999|publisher=McFarland|isbn=078643029X|page=226|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DIxdEZS5ShsC&dq}}</ref>
From 1937 to 1944, the artistic director of Paris-Mondial / Voice of France was [[Tony Aubin]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Randel|first1=Don|title=The Harvard Biographical Dictionary of Music|date=1996|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=0674372999|page=31|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jEGpMqRcQjIC&dq}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Radio France Internationale]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:External services (broadcasting)]] [[Category:Radio stations in France]] [[Category:France in World War II]] [[Category:1937 establishments in France]]

{{Infobox museum |name = Rezhanovce Museum of folk costumes
Режановце Музеј на народни носии |image = |established = |opened = |location = [[Kumanovo]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] |visitors = |director = Zlatko Davitkovski
Златко Давитковски |publictransit = |website = }} The '''Rezhanovce Museum of Folk Costumes''' is a [[museum]] in the village of [[Rezhanovce]] near [[Kumanovo]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]. The museum holds over 800 folk costumes and 400 carpets, mainly from Macedonia, but also from [[Bulgaria]], [[Serbia]], [[Albania]], and [[Greece]], mostly from 19th and 20th century.{{cite web| url=http://www.makdenes.org/content/article/24887147.html | title=Етно-збирка во Режановце прерасна во музеј | website=[http://www.makdenes.org/ makdenes.org] | date=April 8, 2015 }} ==See also== * [[List of museums in the Republic of Macedonia]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://star.vest.com.mk/default.asp?id=86686&idg=5&idb=1313&rubrika=Revija Божјата сила на Злате собра 450 носии на едно место] vest.com.mk 11/13/2004 {{Macedonia-stub}} {{coord missing|Macedonia}} [[Category:Museums with year of establishment missing]] [[Category:Museums in the Republic of Macedonia]] [[Category:Costume museums]] [[Category:Folk museums]] [[Category:Kumanovo Municipality]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Saorsat
| logo = Saorsat logo.png | type = Free-to-air satellite television promotions company | foundation = 3 May 2012{{cite web|url=http://www.saorview.ie/news/saorsat/|title=SAORSAT SATELLITE LIFTS IRELAND TO UNIVERSAL PUBLIC BROADCAST ACCESS.|publisher=Saorview|date=3 May 2012}} | area_served = [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] | Owned_by = | industry = Media | products = Equipment to receive free-to-air digital satellite television channels | revenue = | homepage = {{url|https://www.saorsat.ie/}} }} '''Saorsat''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|ɛər|s|æ|t}} {{respell|SAIR|sat}}; the [[Irish Language|Irish]] word '''Saor''', meaning free, therefore implying '''Freesat''' in [[English Language|English]]) is a [[free-to-air]] satellite service in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]. The service launched on 3 May 2012. ==Overview== The [[RTÉ Network Limited]] (RTÉNL) [[Analog television|analogue terrestrial television]] (ATT) network was never capable of providing 100% population coverage in Ireland. Prior to the digital switchover, ATT population coverage amounted to 98% for [[RTÉ One]] and [[RTÉ Two]], 95% for [[TG4]] and 85% for [[TV3 (Ireland)|TV3]]. [[Saorview]] [[Digital terrestrial television|DTT]] faces a similar difficulty. Broadcasting the channels unencrypted from the [[Astra 28.2°E|Astra 2]] satellites at 28° East was not considered an option due to its large footprint covering the UK, France and many other countries. Irish broadcasters acquire rights on the basis that programming is broadcast to Irish audiences (i.e. some 4.5 million people) and not to approx 100 million people within the Astra footprint. The Board of [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] approved the Saorsat approach developed by RTÉNL from early 2010 to enable the 1-2% of Irish households not covered by Saorview to access free-to-air digital television services. RTÉ submitted a revised DTT plan including the FTA satellite option to the Department of Communications in mid June 2010 for approval.{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/west-the-loser-as-rte-cuts-digital-tv-coverage-2237363.html | work=Irish Independent | first=Brian | last=McDonald | title=West the loser as RTÉ cuts digital TV coverage | date=28 June 2010}} RTÉ publicly announced at an Oireachtas Joint Committee on Communications discussion in mid July 2010 that a free-to-air satellite service, called Saorsat, would be offered to complement the terrestrial DTT service.http://debates.oireachtas.ie/DDebate.aspxF=MAJ20100714.XML&Ex=All&Page=2 {{dead link|date=February 2013}}{{cite news| url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0714/dtt.html | work=RTÉ News | title=RTÉ updates Oireachtas committee on DTT | date=14 July 2010}} The satellite option is a narrow-band satellite operating in the [[Ka band]] as opposed to the normal [[Direct-broadcast satellite|DTH]] [[Ku band]] (which [[Sky (UK and Ireland)|Sky]] and [[Freesat]] use), with a [[spot beam]] being dedicated exclusively to Ireland which will also provide coverage throughout Northern Ireland. The spot beam with frequency reuse means reception in most of Britain and continental Europe is not possible. RTÉ states that the chosen satellite option will cost approximately €1.5 million per year. RTÉ said the combined offering was designed to be the most cost-effective solution for viewers and broadcasters; to offer for the first time 100% coverage of free-to-air public service television services in the Republic of Ireland; and to provide full national back-up coverage on satellite in the event of an emergency or catastrophic failure of the DTT system. Approval for the revised National DTT plan and Saorsat satellite service was announced by the Minister for Communications at the end of July 2010.http://www.dcenr.gov.ie/Press+Releases/New+%e2%82%ac70+million+digital+network+to+be+built+by+RT%c3%89+including+new+satellite+service.htm {{dead link|date=February 2013}} RTÉ did not confirm that Saorsat would broadcast from [[KA-SAT]] until February 2012. There is no other current satellite solution with a spot covering only Ireland. Strictly speaking the spot covers a large part of [[Wales]], [[South West England]] and the [[Hebrides]] of [[Scotland]], but the frequency and polarisation reuse scheme means that no matter how big a dish is used, interference from a similar spot over northern [[France]] would prevent reception much beyond terrestrial overspill into Wales.{{cite web|author=TechTir |url=http://www.techtir.ie/saortv/saorsat-coverage |title=Saorsat Coverage | TechTir |publisher=Techtir.ie |date= |accessdate=2013-02-20}} Reception over all of [[Northern Ireland]] may be possible. At least a Ka band [[Low-noise block downconverter|LNB]], dish and DVB-S2 receiver will be required to receive Saorsat. Reception of Sky or Freesat from the Astra 2 satellites at 28° East will require a separate feed and a [[DiSEqC]] or Multiswitch with a Diseqc compatible receiver. 2rn state that a dish of 1m diameter is required for reception of Saorsat on the island of Ireland.{{cite web |url=https://www.saorview.ie/about-saorview/saorsat/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-06-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610182204/https://www.saorview.ie/about-saorview/saorsat/ |archivedate=10 June 2015 |df=dmy-all }} Saorview is really the RTÉ NL name for the public service broadcaster multiplexes. According to the RTÉ submission to Oireachtas committee the proposed RTÉ NL operated Saorsat is expected to be a copy of Saorview. {{As of|2011|05|28}} the test loop used the same total bitrate as the terrestrial DTT mux.{{cite web|url=http://www.lyngsat.com/eka.html |title=Eutelsat Ka-Sat 9A at 9.0°E - LyngSat |accessdate=2013-02-20}} A dual feed dish (with Ku and Ka LNBFs) or a separate second boxed Cassegrain "dish" is required with a Diseqc switch and HD DVB-S2 tuner to have Freesat and Saorsat on the same set-box or IDTV receiver. RTÉ has made it clear that Saorview/Saorsat will not carry television services from outside the Republic of Ireland and that people in Ireland should seek other digital services to view additional channels other than what is offered.http://debates.oireachtas.ie/DDebate.aspx?F=MAJ20100714.XML&Ex=All&Page=3 {{dead link|date=February 2013}} In contrast, the Irish government has already signed an agreement to permit retransmission of BBC channels.{{cite news| url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0202/1224263582384.html | work=The Irish Times | title=RTÉ and TG4 to be freely available in North in 2012 | date=2 February 2010}} Testing started in May 2011 on KA-SAT 9E, 20.185 GHz DVB-S2 SR25000 FEC 1/2 with pre-recorded material.{{cite web|url=http://wotsat.techradar.com/news/saorsat-testing-ka-sat-31-05-11|title=Saorsat testing on KA-Sat|publisher=What Satellite & Digital TV|date=31 May 2011}} ==Technical== Parameters are: *KA-SAT @ 9E[http://www.lyngsat.com/Eutelsat-9A-and-Ka-Sat-9A.html Eutelsat 9A] www.lyngsat.com. *20.185 GHz, Left Circular Polarisation, *DVB-S2 QPSK, *SR 25000 with 2/3 FEC[http://www.boards.ie/vbulletin/showpost.php?p=89661378&postcount=2824] fec change (was 1/2 FEC which allows about 25 Mbit/s data, about the same as the Terrestrial Mux), *Irish spot (there are 82 spots on KA-SAT) It's likely a second carrier will be used to carry material on the second Terrestrial PSB mux. The second DTT mux is running with no services on many sites and there is a second DVB-S2 carrier in the same part of the Ku band for Internet Services using SR 50000 with adaptive modulation and FEC. Any DVB-S2 HD satellite receiver can in theory be used to receive Saorsat as the Ka band LNBF converts to a regular IF in the 950 MHz to 2,100 MHz band. If the receiver does not have a setting for the Ka band LNBF Lo, then a "fake" frequency 10.765 vertical rather than the real 20.185 may be entered when using the Inverto LNB with local oscillator of 21.2.{{cite web|url=http://www.saortv.info/satellite-saorsat/saorsat-reception/ |title=Saorsat Reception « |publisher=Saortv.info |date= |accessdate=2013-02-20}} To receive [[Freesat]]/Sky or other services alongside Saorsat, a dual- or multi-feed type dish or two dishes are needed with either one or more [[DiSEqC]] switches or a multi-switch. On a multi-switch the Saorsat LNB needs to be connected to vertical 0 kHz port only. The other 3 input ports are left unused. Even with the narrow beam reception is available in the western parts of Scotland, England and Wales[http://www.astra2.org/saorsat.html Saorsat Reception] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130922072719/http://www.astra2.org/saorsat.html |date=22 September 2013 }} with an LNBF on an 80 cm dish pointed at Eutelsat 9E. ==Channels== [[TV3 (Ireland)|Virgin Media One,]] [[3e|Virgin Media Two]] and [[Be3|Virgin Media Three]] do not broadcast on Saorsat, but are available on [[Saorview]]. There is a range of channels for Saorview which are either offered from RTÉNL, or the [[Broadcasting Authority of Ireland|BAI]].http://www.sbpost.ie/post/pages/p/story.aspx-qqqt=MEDIA+AND+MARKETING-qqqs=mediaandmarketing-qqqid=49668-qqqx=1.asp{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{subscription required}} ==See also== *[[Television in Ireland]] *[[RTÉ Network Limited]] *[[Saorview]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} *[http://www.tvchannellists.com/List_of_channels_on_Saorsat_(Ireland) List of channels on Saorsat (Ireland)] [[Category:Satellite television]]
